awd_titl_txt: Investigation of Nucleate Boiling Mechanisms using 3D Transient Temperature Mapping
awd_abstract_narration:
The rapid advancement of nanotechnology and microelectronics poses significant challenges to the thermal management of extreme heat loads discharged from tightly confined areas in electrical systems. Harnessing boiling heat transfer associated with bubble growth is perhaps one of the most efficient cooling methodologies for electrical systems due to the large amount of heat removal during the phase change from water to vapor. Despite significant enhancements in heat removal rates, numerous questions remain regarding the fundamentals of bubble growth mechanisms, a major source of enhanced heat dissipation. The project goal is to develop a mechanistic model for bubble growth that lessens the risk of failure in trial-and-error tests for heat transfer enhancement. This will, in turn, provide a systematic design route for next-generation cooling systems while saving time and money. This project integrates research activities with educational goals such as offering underrepresented minority and female graduate and undergraduate students with hands-on research experiences. 

The research objective of this project is to accurately measure local liquid temperature distributions surrounding a growing bubble that help better explain the heat and mass transfer to bubble growth. Local fluid temperatures in the microlayer are interrogated by total internal reflection thermometry while fluid temperatures in the thermal boundary layer near the liquid-vapor interface are measured by dual-tracer laser-induced fluorescence thermometry. To capture transient temperature distributions, both techniques are combined with high-speed imaging. The transient fluid temperature data are used to quantify time-resolved heat fluxes contributing to mass transfer near the growing bubble. Comprehensive 3D temperature information is also used to validate the existing theoretical and experimental thermal transport models. This project is scientifically significant in that it illuminates the dominant heat transfer mode for fast bubble growth and therefore provides reliable methodologies to engineer surface and fluid properties for enhanced heat transfer without a trial-and-error process.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This research aims to measure local liquid temperatures around bubbles forming in liquids and use the temperature information to understand the mechanisms of heat and mass transfer occurring during boiling. The focus is specifically on the liquid-vapor interfaces on the bubble as it grows. To achieve this goal, we employ a method called dual-tracer fluorescence thermometry. This innovative technique allows for non-invasive, time-dependent temperature measurement using two specially designed tracers that respond to temperature changes. Their emitted light varies with temperature when excited by thin laser light. This approach enables us to obtain detailed temperature information around the bubbles at the microscale and within a very short time frame.

 

One of the primary interests is to investigate how different fin shapes affect bubble growth and the associated heat transfer during boiling. Experiments are conducted in a controlled pool boiling facility that tests various surface conditions. The results indicate that fins with dimpled surfaces exhibit significantly better performance in terms of heat transfer compared to standard flat fins. Specifically, the modified fins achieve about 20% higher heat transfer coefficients. This improvement can be attributed to several factors, including the creation of more nucleation sites for bubble formation, enhanced liquid rewetting, and better dynamics in bubble growth. The ability of the modified fins to facilitate a higher bubble departure frequency, approximately 20% greater at low wall temperatures and up to 35% at high wall temperatures, further supports their effectiveness in improving heat transfer efficiency.

 

Additionally, the temperature measurements provide important insights into the transient temperature behavior near the heated surface and the liquid-vapor interface during bubble departure. The growing bubbles act as dynamic pumps, efficiently removing heat from the surface. This heat removal leads to peak temperature differences of up to 10 °C during the bubble growth and detachment. When comparing these findings with existing literature, we conclude that the heat transfer coefficient near the bubble interface is about 1.3 times higher than that in the surrounding bulk liquid. It must be noted that during bubble growth, the temperature of the liquid remains variant due to the irregular heat transfer from the superheated liquid layer to the liquid-vapor interface. After the bubble departs, the liquid temperature fluctuates, rapidly increasing near the heater just before the bubble detachment.

 

Furthermore, we explore how the orientation of the surface impacts bubble dynamics and the resultant heat transfer performance. By varying the surface orientation from horizontal to vertical, we found that the base diameter of the bubbles increases throughout the ebullition cycle. This change is largely due to the buoyancy forces acting on the bubbles. The larger base diameter contributes to increased bubble departure sizes and a reduction in bubble departure frequencies. It is also observed that the heat transfer coefficient decreases as the surface orientation increases, which was attributed to longer bubble residence times on the heated surface.

 

These primary findings emphasize the significant advantages of artificial nucleation sites in enhanced heat transfer performance during nucleate boiling. Surfaces with artificial nucleation sites demonstrate higher bubble departure diameters and growth rates compared to surfaces without such sites. High-speed imaging of the bubble ebullition cycle reveals that a rapid bubble nucleation cycle occurs at artificial sites, which leads to lower local wall temperatures and, consequently, more effective heat removal from the heated surface. One interesting observation from the study is that the temperature distributions around a single bubble are nearly uniform during initiation. However, this uniformity changes to an uneven distribution during bubble growth due to the formation of a superheated liquid layer, which then returns to uniformity during the bubble departure, facilitated by the expansion of the superheated liquid layer.

 

Overall, this research contributes significantly to our understanding of bubble growth in nucleate boiling, which is crucial for designing and developing advanced cooling technologies. Effective vapor bubble growth is essential for achieving high cooling capacities in various applications, as bubbles can efficiently remove substantial amounts of heat from hot spots. The project addresses the ongoing challenge of developing widely accepted bubble growth models, which have previously been hindered by a lack of reliable transient temperature data surrounding bubbles. The measurements of local, time-resolved temperature distributions at two-phase interfaces enable the calculation of local heat fluxes and the identification of crucial heat and mass transfer processes that facilitate bubble growth.

 

The findings from this research are expected to validate future bubble growth models in boiling heat transfer and may lead to the development of new predictive models. Additionally, the research provides the first experimental estimates of local heat transfer coefficients near growing bubbles, addressing a crucial gap in the existing literature. This comprehensive approach can bridge existing knowledge gaps and improve the effectiveness of heat transfer technologies.



 


Last Modified: 10/29/2024
Modified by: Myeongsub Kim
